pdf.title: PDF (Portable Document Format)
pdf.explanation: PDF is a format designed for presenting documents in a manner independent of application software, hardware, and operating systems. It encapsulates a complete description of a fixed-layout flat document, including text, fonts, vector graphics, raster images and other information needed to display it.
pdf.use_case: Use PDF when you want to ensure your document looks the same everywhere, for official documents, forms, and for sharing files that shouldn't be easily modified.
pdf.security_notes: PDFs can contain executable code (JavaScript) and active content, which can be a security risk. Always be cautious opening PDFs from untrusted sources. They can also be used in phishing attacks.

docx.title: DOCX (Office Open XML Document)
docx.explanation: DOCX is the file format developed by Microsoft for Word. It's an XML-based format that is designed for easy editing and modification. It stores text, formatting, images, tables, and more.
docx.use_case: Use DOCX when you need to collaborate on a document that will be edited by multiple people, especially if they are using Microsoft Word.
docx.security_notes: DOCX files can contain macros, which are scripts that can be used to automate tasks but can also contain malware. Always be wary of enabling macros from untrusted documents.

txt.title: TXT (Plain Text)
txt.explanation: The simplest of all text formats. It contains no formatting information, only plain text characters. It is universally compatible with nearly every program.
txt.use_case: Use TXT for notes, configuration files, or any situation where you need maximum compatibility and no rich text formatting.
txt.security_notes: TXT files are generally very safe as they cannot contain executable code. However, they can still contain links to malicious websites.

json.title: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)
json.explanation: JSON is a lightweight data-interchange format. It is easy for humans to read and write and easy for machines to parse and generate. It is based on a subset of JavaScript.
json.use_case: JSON is the standard for transmitting data between a server and a web application (APIs). It's also widely used for configuration files.
json.security_notes: JSON itself is just data and is safe. The risk comes from how the data is processed. Never use `eval()` to parse JSON from an untrusted source, as it can lead to code execution vulnerabilities.

csv.title: CSV (Comma-Separated Values)
csv.explanation: A CSV file is a delimited text file that uses a comma to separate values. Each line of the file is a data record. Each record consists of one or more fields, separated by commas.
csv.use_case: CSV is a common format for exchanging tabular data between spreadsheet programs and databases. It's simple and widely supported.
csv.security_notes: CSV files are generally safe. However, they can be subject to 'CSV Injection,' where a cell starting with `=`, `+`, `-`, or `@` could be interpreted as a formula by spreadsheet software, potentially leading to data exfiltration or other attacks if the file is opened.

markdown.title: Markdown (MD)
markdown.explanation: Markdown is a lightweight markup language for creating formatted text using a plain-text editor. It's designed to be easy to read and write.
markdown.use_case: Used for writing documentation, README files, blog posts, and forum messages. It can be converted to structurally valid HTML.
markdown.security_notes: When rendered into HTML, Markdown from an untrusted source must be sanitized to prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. For example, a user could include a malicious `<script>` tag in their markdown.

general_security.title: General File Security
general_security.online_converters: Be extremely cautious with online file converters. Many upload your file to their servers, where you lose control over your data. For sensitive information, always use a trusted, client-side tool like this one.
general_security.file_extensions: A file's extension (like .pdf or .txt) can be easily faked. Attackers might name a virus 'report.pdf.exe'. Always be mindful of the true file type and be suspicious of unexpected double extensions.
